2005.question: 1. Which of the following steps in the scientific method comes following observation?
2. The main component of the plant cell wall is _______________?
3. Which of the following classes of enzymes digests carbohydrates?
4. Which of the following kingdoms of life is consisting of prokaryotic organisms?
5. Which component of soil fertility is improved when farmers grow legumes in crop rotation?
6. Before making crosses, which part of the flower did Mendel remove to avoid self pollination?
7. Which one of the following do bees use to inform other bees about the location and distance of a new source of nectar they discover?
8. One of the following molecules is the building units of an enzyme molecule.
9. Which one of the following is the main constituent of biological membranes?
10. One of the following biomes in Africa is supporting large wild mammals such as elephants, giraffes and lions.

options.option: B. The Rain Forest of Western Ethiopia

2005.question: 11. Which of the following is the correct F2 phenotypic ratio of a monohybrid cross?
12. How many carbon atoms are there in one disaccharide molecule?
13. Which unit is best to use for measuring the smallest cells and organelles?
14. Which energy rich organic compound contains adenine in its molecule?
15. What are the most frequent causative agents of food poisoning?
16. What are the most likely causes of variations within species?
17. In which hominid species did scientists find the smallest brain size(cranial capacity)?
18. Which of the following is NOT classified as a learned behaviour?
19. What is the specialist in biology called if he/she studies fossils to generate new knowledge on the origin and evolution of living things of past geologic periods?
20. All proteins contain carbon, hydrogen, oxygen and what other element?
21. What makes unsaturated fatty acids different from saturated fatty acids?

options.option: A. The presence of long chain of carbon.
B. The presence of one or more double bonds.
C. The presence of large number of hydrogen atoms.
D. Their occurrence as solid at room temperature.

2005.question: 22. Which of the following pairs of molecules are known to have catalytic activity?
23. If a suspension of a mixture of cellular organelles is spun in a centrifuge, which organelle settles to the bottom first?
24. During chemiosmosis, what substance diffuses from one side to the other side of the membrane?
25. Which of the following human diseases can be prevented by taking proper diets?
26. When two species are compared, which of the following sources of evidence is least informative about the degree of relationships between the species?

options.option: B. Amino acid sequences of proteins

2005.question: 27. Which of the following practices does NOT normally transmit HIV?
28. What is the important role played by microorganisms such as bacteria and fungi in the ecosystem?

options.option: D. Supplying energy to the ecosystem

2005.question: 29. In which one of the following aspects is the tropical rainforest biome poor?
30. If the size of a cell increases, which one of the following gets smaller?

options.option: A. The volume of the cell
B. The surface area of the cell
C. Surface area to volume ratio of the cell
D. Volume to surface area ratio of the cell

2005.question: 31. Which of the following is NOT usually true as an ecological succession progresses to advanced seral stages?

options.option: A. More ecological niches are formed
C. The depth of the soil increases

2005.question: 32. One of the following is an important cause of gene mutation.
33. What is the reproductive isolating mechanism called if two species of frogs do not interbreed because they cannot understand the mating calls of one another?
34. How many chromosomes do humans inherit from each of their parents?
35. In which one of the four phases of population growth is the number of the population the highest?
36. Which of the following is NOT true about the gene called SRY?

options.option: A. It is found on the Y-chromosome.
C. Testes develop in its presence.
D. Females have two copies of this gene.

2005.question: 37. To which of the following groups do those bacteriophages that integrate their DNA into the chromosome of their bacterial host belong?
38. What do we call the learned behaviour if a mouse that had just escaped from the mouth of a cat jumped violently at a slight touch by a trivial object?
39. Which of the following theories explains evolutionary changes of living things in terms of changes in their allele frequencies?
40. Which of the following is an important function of the Golgi apparatus?

options.option: B. Packaging of proteins for export out of the cell
C. Removing of debris from cell
D. Storage of waste materials not needed by the cell

2005.question: 41. Which of the following field equipment is used to determine an exact location of a place?
42. The sheep 'dolly' is an example of which biotechnological manipulation of animals by human?
43. Among the following, which one is the best criterion to show that two populations belong to same species?

options.option: C. Inhabiting the same geographic area

2005.question: 44. In the process of the evolution of life on earth, which of the following four processes evolved last?
45. What is a theory in biology?

options.option: A. The outcome of an experiment
B. A proof that shows the hypothesis is true
C. A hypothesis supported by experiments and/or observations
D. An opinion or educated guess resulting from observations

2005.question: 46. For which of the following is a theodolite used in biology education?

options.option: A. Measuring the height of trees.
B. Recording positions where a species is found.
C. Measuring the rate of flow of water in a cell.
D. Measuring the pH of water or soil.

2005.question: 47. What is the name of the sugar found in milk?
48. To which class of enzymes do the digestive enzymes belong?
49. In which of the following features are eukaryotic cells distinguished from prokaryotic cells?
50. What will happen if human red blood cells are kept in a hypotonic solution?

options.option: A. Lose water by osmosis and burst.
B. Lose water by osmosis and shrink.
C. Take in water by osmosis, swell and burst.
D. Take in water by osmosis, swell and remain turgid.

2005.question: 51. In which type of solution is the water potential more negative than in the cells?

options.option: D. Equal solute and solvent concentration

2005.question: 52. Which of the following paired organelles are membrane-bound?

55. Choose the one that is different from all the others.
56. Under which of the following groups can the fungi be more conveniently placed?
57. What is the type of community called when it has reached the final and most complex stage of a succession?
58. Which of the following is an ecosystem?

options.option: C. All the organisms in a given area
D. The non-living components of an environment

2005.question: 59. Which of the following crops is considered to be the best choice for a better balance of essential amino acids as a human diet?
60. What is the main reason for the high species richness of plants and mammals observed in Ethiopia?

options.option: C. Presence of several biomes within the country
D. Effcient management of the ecological resources

2005.question: 61. In which of the following are flowers and fruits found?
62. In a cross between heterozygotes what proportion is expected to be homozygous recessive?

66. Which one of the following concepts contains all the others?
67. Choose the one that is NOT a requirement of all living things.
68. What is the advantage of using HAART (highly active anti- retroviral therapy) for the treatment of HIV?

options.option: A. It gives a lasting immunity to HIV,
B. It prevents mutation of HIV.
C. It prevents reinfection by HIV.
D. It helps to break the life cycle of HIV.

2005.question: 69. Which of the following characteristics can show the evolutionary relationships among organisms?
70. The group of the Ethiopian wolf which does NOT contribute to territory marking with their urine containing pheromones is
71. What can one conclude about the contents of the foodstuff if a mixture of Benedict solution and a foodstuff remain blue after heating?
72. Which of the following types of enzyme inhibitions can be removed when the end product of the metabolic pathway is depleted?

options.option: A. Its reaction center molecule is P680.
B. It passes its excited electrons to Photosystem-I.
C. The energy lost from its excited electrons reduces NADP.
D. It replenishes its lost electrons from photolysis of water.

2005.question: 75. On which one of the following principles are most of the anti-HIV drugs currently in use working?
76. Among the following mating, where the ABO blood genotypes of the partners are shown, identify the mating in which all the children will have the same blood type.
77. If a new mutant allele arises in a certain population, which of the following factors determines if the allele is going to be adaptive or non-adaptive?

options.option: A. The environment in which the population lives.
B. The rate at which the gene mutates.
C. The population in which the gene is found.
D. The use and disuse of the gene by the population.

2005.question: 78. Which of the following is the correct route that connects a stimulus and a response?
79. Which of the following contents RNA differs from DNA?
80. Which of the following cell types can be rich in lysosomes?
81. What is the importance of chemiosmosis in photosynthesis and cellular respiration?
82. If the age pyramid of a certain country is narrowing at the base, what does this tell about the trend of the population size of the country? The population size is:
83. Suppose the amino acid coding region in a mRNA is 1200 nucleotides long, how long is the protein in terms of amino acid number?
84. If a new anti-HIV drug is to be developed to prevent the virus from entering the host cell, which one of the following processes should the drug target?

options.option: B. Binding of Gp120 and CD4
C. Integration of viral DNA into host DNA
D. Assembly of viral parts into a whole Virus

2005.question: 85. Which one of the following factors is NOT important for evolutionary change of a population?

options.option: D. Survival of all that are born

2005.question: 86. One of the following would be harder to see under the ordinary light microscope that is more likely to be available in school laboratories.
87. In some human liver cells there are 92 chromosomes per cell. What is the ploidy level of such cells?
88. Which of the following groups of substances are all inorganic?

options.option: B. Sugar, fatty acid, amino acid
C. Water, calcium carbonate, carbon dioxide
D. Carbon dioxide, amino acid, fatty acid

2005.question: 89. In which of the following compounds are both members of the pair are polymers Of carbohydrates that naturally occur in plants only?
90. Which of the following is generally expected to give better health benefits when present in human diet?
91. Where does the light dependent reaction of photosynthesis occur in the chloroplast?

options.option: B. In the fluid of the stroma
C. In all parts of the chloroplast

2005.question: 92. For which of the following is the sugar produced by photosynthesis NOT used?

options.option: C. To produce ATP in respiration.

2005.question: 93. In which process is ATP generated during short distance high speed running?
94. Which one of the following choices shows the end products of a mitotic cell division?
95. What exactly happens during a substitution mutation?

options.option: A. One base is replaced by a different base.
B. An extra base is added during DNA replication.
C. A base is missed out during DNA replication.
D. Changes occur in the arrangement or structure of a chromosome.

2005.question: 96. During the course of evolution, which of the following events came before all the others?

options.option: A. Origin of dinosaurs and other reptiles.
B. Availability of free oxygen in the atmosphere.
C. Origin of the oldest eukaryotic organisms.
D. Origin of the first multicellular animals and plants.

2005.question: 97. What kind of natural selection is at work in a situation where individuals at both extreme ends of the range get better survival advantages than those around the middle?

options.option: D. Selection that removes the extremes

2005.question: 98. In which geologic period does the fossil record show more diverse and relatively higher forms of organisms?
99. To what kind of animal behaviour can the spinning of a web by a spider be classified?
100. Which of the following is a recently developed active area of research in biology today?

options.option: B. Study about the cell theory

2006.question: 1. Behavior that is repeated on a daily basis is referred to as:

options.option: A. Both matter and energy are recycled
B. Matter is NOT recycled; energy is recycled
C. Matter is recycled; energy is NOT recycled
D. Energy is recycled more than matter does

2006.question: 14.Which Of the following is true about protozoa?

options.option: A. They are a group of bacteria
C. They represent both plants and animals

options.option: A. They act inside cells only
D. They operate at any pH

33. Into which of the following organic compounds can lipase, maltase and sucrase be grouped?
34. Which of the following substances is NOT necessary for photosynthesis to take place?
35. Which of the following PH values represents the strongest base?
36. Which of the following is an accurate representation of the relationships between the terms metabolism, anabolism and catabolism?
37. What is the ultimate source of energy for all organisms living on the earth?
38. Which of the following can be taken as case for evidence of evolution from the field of plant and animal breeding?

options.option: A. Artificial breeding always creates new species
B. Artificial breeding only produces new organisms with higher yield
C. Artificial breeding shows that natural Selection can produce variations .
D. Artificial breeding can produce new variations in organisms

2006.question: 39. In which of the activities of the honey bee colony are worker bees involved?

options.option: D. Taking care of the larvae

2006.question: 40. Choose the characteristics that viruses share with living things.

options.option: A. They are made up of many specialized cells

2006.question: 41. According to Lamarck's theory of evolution, what is the mechanism by which evolving organisms acquire new structures?

options.option: C.Use - and - disuse of parts of the body

2006.question: 42. Where exactly in the cell does the Krebs cycle take place?
43. In which one of the following ways the Tundra biome differs from desert biome?

options.option: A. It is a treeless biome
D. It has permanently frozen subsoil

options.option: A. In the breathing processes of all animals
B. In the decomposition of organic molecules
C. In the process of photosynthesis by green plants
D. In all the cellular respiration processes of organisms

options.option: A. They have single bonds between carbon atoms
B. They are the same as polyunsaturated fatty acids
C. They are the same as monounsaturated fatty acids
D. They have double bonds between the carbon atoms

options.option: A. Low rainfall and high temperature
B. Low rainfall and low temperature
C. High rainfall and high temperature
D. High rainfall and low temperature

2006.question: 61. Which one of the following characteristics is UNNECESSARY for an object to be considered living thing?

options.option: A. Ability to respond to stimuli

options.option: A. A flower with petals and pistil
B. A flower with stamens and sepals
C. A flower with stamens and pistil
D. A flower with sepals and petals

options.option: B. Clearing forests to grow crops
C. Growing crops of improved varieties

options.option: A. Conversion of viral RNA to DNA
B. Replication of the viral genome
C. Insertion of the viral genome into host genome
D. Release of the viral progeny from the cell

options.option: A. They are made up of glucose and fructose
B. They are made up of amino acids and glycerol
C. have double bonds in their carbon chains
D. They have only single bonds at the points of attachment

options.option: A. Wing of a bird and wing of a butterfly
B. Front leg of a horse and a human arm
C. Wing of a bird and wing of a bat
D. FrOnt leg of a frog and Wing of a bat

options.option: D. In both hypotopic and hypertonic solutions

options.option: A. The oxygen content of the water
B. The nitrogen content of the water
C. The elevation where the lake is found
D. The amount of the penetrates the lake water

options.option: A. AIDS is the virus and HIV is the disease
B. Both AIDS and HIV refer to the disease
C. AIDS is the disease and HIV is the virus
D. Both AIDS and HIV refer to the virus

options.option: A. The human species began life in the ocean
B. The human species and whales share a common ancestry
C. Whales are older than the human species
D. Whales have evolved from early humans that went back to the ocean

options.option: A. People who received the placebo
B. People who received the new drug
D. The new drug and the placebo

options.option: A. The cell will become turgid
B. The central vacuole will expand
C. The protoplasm will get plasmolysed
D. The cell will swell and burst

options.option: D. Complete lack of metabolic processes

options.option: A. They added oxygen and chlorophyll to the environment
B. They added carbon dioxide to the environment
C. They stored energy in the bonds of inorganic compounds
D. They manufactured food from carbon dioxide and oxygen

2007.question: 1. Which of the following step of the scientific method comes before all the rest?

5. Which of the following units of measurement is more convenient to express the size of cellular organelles?

options.option: A. They never lead to cancerous cells.
B. They never pass to the next generation.
C. They never damage the affected cells.
D. There is no way that they kill the affected cells.

2007.question: 18. What is the process called when two bacteria directly contact cell to cell and exchange their genetic information?
19. Why is it that mutations are considered as one of the raw materials of evolution?

options.option: A. They contribute to new variations in organisms.
B. They are usually related to the environment in which they appear.
C. They are mostly beneficial to the organism in which they appear.
D. They usually become the causes for species extinction.

2007.question: 20. Which of the following is consistent with the understanding of human evolution?

options.option: A. Bipedalism was never important in human evolution.
B. Larger brain size had no contribution to the evolution of the human species.
C. Human ancestry had no relation whatsoever with that of the chimpanzees.
D. Fossils of Lucy and Ardi provided evidence for human origin.

2007.question: 21. If certain food stuff gave a positive result with Benedict's test only after it was hydrolyzed with hydrochloric acid, which of the following substances could it be?

options.option: C. To prepare report of the result

options.option: A. cell is covered by a single membrane.
B. A membrane is only one lipid layer thick.
C. All cells have essentially similar membrane.
D. A membrane is covered by a single layer of protein.

options.option: C. CD4 on the membrane surface.
D. Pores in the cell membrane.

options.option: B. Function of the organelle in the cell.

options.option: A. It can be developed further through learning.
B. It is triggered by a key stimulus.
C. It has a fixed action pattern.
D. It is adaptive for the species.

options.option: A. Their genetic material is DNA.
B. Their genetic material is RNA.

D. They copy RNA from DNA molecule.

B. To insert plasmid into bacteria.
C. To multiply copies of DNA molecule.

options.option: A. It will protect from harmful solar rays.
B. It will increase the global temperature.
C. It will reduce the atmospheric CO2.
D. It will mend the holes in the ozone layer.
